I. 

THE PROPOSAL  

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC) 
Corridor 6 (Marakand–Karshi) Railway Electrification Project.1 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
2. 
The  project  is  located  in  the  remote  and  less  developed  districts  of  Samarkand  and 
Kashkadarya  provinces.  To  support  Uzbekistan’s  railway  development,  the  project  will  finance 
the  electrification  of  the  140  kilometers  (km)  Marakand–Karshi  section  of  CAREC  Corridor  6. 
This railway upgrade will increase regional connectivity, cut transport costs, lessen greenhouse 
gas emissions, and boost trade.2 
 
3. 
With three CAREC corridors crossing its territory, Uzbekistan is a key transit country for 
trade in Central Asia. The project is part of the government’s railway development strategy;3 it is 
aligned  with  Strategy  2020 4 of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  is  included  in  the 
country  operations  business  plan,  2011–2013.5 It  is  also  part  of  the  CAREC  Transport  and 
Trade  Facilitation  Strategy  and  Action  Plan6 and  aligned  with  the  Uzbekistan  Transport  Sector 
Strategy, 2006–2020.7 
  
4. 
Uzbekistan’s  railway  network  has  a  track  gauge  of  1,520  millimeters  and  is  4,593  km 
long  (681  km  of  double  line  and  the  remainder  being  single  line).  Railways  are  crucial  to  the 
economy,  meeting  specific  transport  demand  such  as  for  bulk  haul  of  minerals  and  freight, 
intercity  passenger  services,  and  commuter  services  in  urban  areas.  Annually,  railways  carry 
about 75 million tons of freight and 15 million passengers. The entire rail system, managed by 
the  state  joint-stock  company  Uzbekistan  Temir  Yullari  (UTY),  needs  to  be  modernized  and 
institutionally strengthened. ADB has supported the sector by investing in the rehabilitation and 
modernization  of  infrastructure.  The  government  began  reforming  the  railway  sector  in  1997, 
and  ADB  supported  this  effort  through  technical  assistance.8 Ancillary  services  were  largely 
separated from core rail operations. Public and private forwarding organizations with marketing 
responsibilities have been established. Reforms are yielding results but institutional constraints 
need  to  be  reduced  to  realize  the  sector’s  potential.  Overall,  railways  are  profitable  and  have 
been able to finance their own infrastructure rehabilitation and modernization. 
 

                                                 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  project  preparatory  technical  assistance.  ADB.  2011.  Technical 

Assistance to Uzbekistan for Preparing the Railway Electrification Investment Program. Manila. 

3  The  government  has  formulated  the  Railway  Electrification  Program  up  to  2020  (Decree  of  the  President  of  the 
Republic  of  Uzbekistan  No.  PP-993,  5  November  2008)  and  prioritized  under  Decree  of  the  President  of  the 
Republic  of  Uzbekistan  No.  PP-1446,  21  December  2010,  a  three-part  5-year  railway  capital  investment  plan, 
2011–2015  with  an  estimated  cost  of  $1.87  billion:  (i)  further  development  of  railway  infrastructure,  (ii)  railway 
electrification, and (iii) modernization of rolling stock. 

4  ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  2008–2020. 

Manila. 

5  ADB. 2011. Country Operations Business Plan: Uzbekistan, 2011–2013. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2008. CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy and Action Plan. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2006. Transport Sector Strategy (2006–2020). Consultant’s Report. Manila (TA 4659-UZB). 
8  ADB.  1998.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  Institutional  Strengthening  of  the  Uzbekistan 
Temir  Yullari.  Manila  (TA  3068-UZB);  ADB.  2000.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for 
Facilitating Development of the Railway Sector. Manila (TA 3529-UZB). 

 2 

 

The  north–south  corridor  linking  Europe  through  Central  Asia  to  the  Middle  East  and 
5. 
South Asia (CAREC Corridor 6) transits Uzbekistan from Keles on the border with Kazakhstan 
to Tashkent, Samarkand, Karshi, and Kumkurgan, before reaching Termez on the border with 
Afghanistan. The corridor annually carries about 10 million tons of freight, including 1.6 million 
tons  of  humanitarian  relief  goods  to  Afghanistan  (more  than  half  its  imports).  Afghanistan 
expects more traffic from Uzbekistan and its northern neighbors via the corridor, especially after 
the  ADB-funded  Hairatan  to  Mazar-e-Sharif  railway  in  northern  Afghanistan  was  completed  in 
2010.9 The corridor will also enable the Uzbekistan provinces of Samarkand, Kashkadarya, and 
Surkhandarya  to  increase  exports  of  cotton  and  its  by-products,  horticulture  products,  marble, 
oil, and gas. Overall, rail traffic is increasing and inadequate rail line capacity in some sections 
of the route creates bottlenecks. 
 
The northern part of this rail corridor from Keles to Marakand is electrified and operated 
6. 
by electric locomotives, increasing capacity and improving freight and passenger services. The 
remaining  part  of  the  rail  corridor  from  Marakand  to  Termez  is  currently  operated  by  less 
powerful  diesel  locomotives,  and  the  slow,  short  trains  limit  throughput  in  the  section. 
Electrification  will  help  overcome  capacity  constraints  and  meet  current  and  future  traffic 
demand.  From  Karshi  to  Termez,  electrification  is  in  progress,  cofinanced  by  UTY  and  the 
Government  of  Japan.  The  Government  of  Uzbekistan  has  requested  ADB  assistance  for 
electrification on the remaining section from Marakand to Karshi.  
 
7. 
Besides  providing  transport  to  remote  and  less  developed  districts  of  Samarkand  and 
Kashkadarya  provinces,  the  Marakand–Karshi  rail  line  links  with  three  main  railway  routes: 
northeast to Samarkand, Tashkent, and onward to Kazakhstan; northwest to Nukus, Urgench, 
and Kazakhstan; and south to Termez and onward to Afghanistan, with links to Tajikistan and 
Turkmenistan.  Complete  electrification  of  the  whole  route  from  Keles  to  Termez  will  bring  the 
benefits of uninterrupted electric traction for end-to-end movement of rail traffic. Upgrading the 
rail corridor will foster regional cooperation and promote regional development. 
 
8. 
ADB’s  assistance  in  Uzbekistan’s  transport  sector  is  satisfactory,  and  the  government 
and  development  partners  recognize  transport  as  one  of  ADB’s  main  areas  of  expertise.10 As 
the lead development partner in Uzbekistan’s rail transport subsector, ADB extended two loans 
for  railway  development—$70  million  for  the  Railway  Rehabilitation  Project  in  1998  and  $70 
million  for  the  Railway  Modernization  Project  in  2000.  ADB’s  project  completion  reports  and 
project  performance  evaluation  report 11  confirmed  both  projects’  success  and  rated  the 
performance of the government and the executing agency, UTY, highly satisfactory. The project 
design  incorporates  key  lessons  from  ADB’s  experience  in  the  transport  sector  in  Uzbekistan, 
including  (i)  completing  tender  results  and  price  verifications  before  submitting  the  bid 
evaluation  report  to  ADB  for  contract  award,  (ii)  strengthening  the  executing  agency’s  project 
implementation capacity with consulting services for construction supervision, and (iii) obtaining 
the  government’s  and  UTY’s  assurances  for  adequate  funding  for  satisfactory  maintenance  of 
the project line to assist the safe operation of freight and passenger train services. 
                                                 
9   ADB. 2009. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Asian Development 
Fund  Grant  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Afghanistan  for  the  Hairatan  to  Mazar-e-Sharif  Railway  Project.  Manila.  A 
UTY subsidiary has been contracted to operate and maintain this new rail line in Afghanistan. The cross-border rail 
transport  facilitation  arrangements  between  Uzbekistan  and  Afghanistan  are  being  finalized,  which  will  maximize 
the economic benefits of this international corridor. 

10  ADB. 2011. Country Assistance Program Evaluation: Uzbekistan. Manila (CAP: UZB 2011–17). 
11  ADB.  2006.  Completion  Report:  Railway  Rehabilitation  Project  in  Uzbekistan.  Manila  (Loan  1631-UZB);  ADB. 
2008.  Completion  Report:  Railway  Modernization  Project  in  Uzbekistan.  Manila  (Loan  1773-UZB);  ADB.  2010. 
Project Performance Evaluation Report of Railway Rehabilitation and Railway Modernization in Uzbekistan. Manila 
(Loan 1631-UZB and Loan 1773-UZB).  

 Impact and Outcome 

The  impact  will  be  increased  regional  trade  and  accelerated  economic  growth.  The 

B. 
 
9. 
outcome will be improved railway operation on the Marakand–Karshi rail line. 
 
C. 
 
10. 
The outputs will comprise (i) a 140 km electrified rail line from Marakand to Karshi and 
(ii)  improved  management  capacity  of  UTY.  The  project  envisages  design  speeds  of 
160 km/hour for passenger services and 100 km/hour for freight services on the project route. 
The project components are described below: 

Outputs 

Railway  electrification.  The  project  will  include  (a)  constructing  an  overhead 
catenary  system  (OCS)  consisting  of  two  wires  (for  carrying  alternating  current 
27.5-kilovolt  power  for  electric  traction),  supported  by  sloping  hangers  fixed  to 
concrete posts along the railway line; (b) constructing three traction substations 
in the project section at intervals of about 50 km; (c) providing local and remote 
controls  for  monitoring  and  supervision  of  power  supply  using  the  supervisory 
control  and  data  acquisition  system;  and  (d)  upgrading  associated  track 
facilities. 12  The  project  will  also  upgrade  signaling  with  computer-based 
interlocking and communications systems to facilitate efficient operations. These 
systems  are  compatible  with  electrification  and  are  protected  against 
electromagnetic  interference  caused  by  high-voltage  electric  traction.  The 
upgraded  communications  system  will  link  traction  substations  with  nearby 
railway stations. 

Maintenance  facilities.  The  project  will  develop  maintenance  facilities  for 
electric locomotives by refitting the Karshi depot currently used to maintain diesel 
locomotives. The facilities in the existing depot and a subdepot about 3 km away 
will be consolidated to improve efficiency by reducing downtime for maintenance 
and  improving  asset  use.  The  project  will  also  procure  specialized  equipment, 
including  motor  vehicles;  breakdown  vehicles;  motor  vehicle-mounted  drilling 
machines;  and  protection  facilities  and  a  small  powered  plant  for  inspection, 
maintenance, and attending to major breakdowns of OCS. 

Institutional  capacity  improvement.  The  project  will  improve  the  institutional 
capacity  of  UTY  through  (a)  workshops  and  gender-sensitive  training  sessions 
for  UTY  management  and  key  technical  staff,  which  will  improve  corporate 
governance and managerial skills and optimize costs to improve corporate social 
responsibility  and  profitability;  (b)  training  of  UTY  staff,  specifically  in  project 
management  and  crosscutting  areas  relevant  to  railway  development;  and        
(c) upgrading of the technology and skills of UTY staff through training in the use 
and  maintenance  of  state-of-the-art  equipment  for  the  project  procured  from 
international  sources,  including  testing  and  commissioning  of  equipment  under 
actual conditions of operation.  

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

 

                                                 
12  The project will upgrade the line and level of the rail tracks to the design standard before OCS installation. A total 
of 21 km of track curves will be realigned. Arrangements will be provided at some bridges for installing support for 
OCS  and  for  carrying  communication  cables  across  the  bridge  spans.  Tracks  at  stations  will  be  lengthened  to 
1,050 meters in accordance with the standard for electrified sections to ease the operation of longer and heavier 
trains with electric traction. Additional siding tracks will be provided to service traction substations. Track works will 
make use of some recycled materials. 

3 

 

 Investment and Financing Plans 

1.

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 

2. 

Financing Plan 

  
The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $100  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
12. 
resources (OCR) to help finance the project. The government and UTY will finance the balance. 
The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, an annual interest rate 
determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending 
facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  year  (the  interest  and  other  charges  during 
construction will not be capitalized in the loan), and such other terms and conditions set forth in 
the draft loan and project agreements. The loan proceeds will be relent to UTY on ADB’s OCR 
loan terms pursuant to a subsidiary loan agreement. Foreign exchange risk will be assumed by 
UTY.  The  loan  will  cover  costs  of  plant,  materials  and  equipment,  project  management, 
institutional  capacity  improvement,  and  part  of  contingencies.  The  government  and  UTY  will 
finance  local  taxes  and  duties,  civil  works,  materials  and  equipment,  recurrent  cost,  financing 
charges, and part of contingencies. The government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for 
its  decision  to  borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility  based  on  these  terms  and 
conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not 
made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. The financing plan is in Table 2.

D. 
 

 
11. 

 

 Implementation Arrangements 

E. 
 
13. 
UTY will be the executing agency. It has established a project implementation unit (PIU) 
and  appointed  the  project  director  and  key  staff  to  deal  with  procurement;  engineering 
(signaling,  telecommunications,  and  electrification  and  civil  works);  project  accounts;  and  staff 
training. PIU staff members have experience in implementing and managing similar projects.13 
Technical departments of UTY will also assist the PIU. An international firm will be recruited in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time)  to  (i)  help  the  PIU  supervise  project  implementation  and  manage  contracts;  (ii)  provide 
hands-on  training  in  project  management  and  oversight,  operation  and  maintenance,  and 
reporting; and (iii) improve institutional capacity.  
 
All procurement financed under the ADB loan will follow international competitive bidding 
14. 
procedures pursuant to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB’s prior review procedures will be followed. UTY will include the relevant sections of ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) in all bidding and contractual documents. Civil 
works and supply of materials and equipment from ADB non-member countries will be financed 
by UTY from its own resources and procured under existing government procedures consistent 
with the principles of economy and efficiency. 
 
Project  implementation  will  take  about  4.5  years.  Advance  procurement  actions  to 
15. 
expedite  project  implementation  will  be  considered  in  line  with  ADB’s  procurement  and 
consulting  services  guidelines.  The  loan  closing  is  expected  by  30  September  2016.  The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the project 
administration manual.14

5 

 

 III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

the 

Technical 

A. 
 
The  technical  viability  of  the  equipment,  facilities,  and  technology  selected,  and  the 
16. 
modality  of  implementation  were  assessed,  considering  the  available  capacity  and  areas  that 
need  to  be  improved.  The  design  features  and  construction  standards  for  electrification  were 
reviewed  for  sustainability  of  the  technology,  and  local  capacity  for  successful  operation  and 
maintenance of the electrified railway line. 
 
17. 
Electrification  of  the  single  line  from  Marakand  to  Karshi  will  help  reduce  capacity 
constraints in the section. The modality of implementation of various components is guided by 
principles of efficiency, economy, and the need for technology improvements in UTY and staff 
training.  The  project  includes  international  competitive  bidding  (ICB)  procurement  of  design, 
supply,  and  installation  of  plant  for  traction  substations,  power  control  equipment  (supervisory 
control  and  data  acquisition),  and  signaling  and  telecommunications  systems.  Antiquated 
signaling  and  telecommunications  equipment  (1970s  vintage)  needs  to  be  upgraded.  The 
current  equipment  does  not  protect  against  the  effects  of  electromagnetic  interference  caused 
by 
installation  of  27.5-kilovolt  railway  electrification.  State-of-the-art  signaling  and 
telecommunications equipment and the associated staff training under the project will help UTY 
to  update  existing  technology  and  spread  the  benefits  to  the  entire  system.  Using  equipment 
procured through ICB, UTY will implement OCS, including sectioning posts, and refitting of the 
diesel locomotive depot at Karshi to maintain electric locomotives. 
 
OCS will be implemented and the Karshi depot refitted under normal traffic operations, 
18. 
without  disrupting  and/or  stopping  train  services.  Works  requiring  blocking  of  the  line  will  be 
carried  out  during  window  times  between  trains.  During  construction,  vital  rail  operation 
installation  must  be  kept  secure,  especially  because  the  project  area  is  close  to  a  region  of 
ongoing conflict. The arrangements for constructing these facilities consider the related issues 
of  security  (of  existing  installations)  and  safety  of  train  operations  and  workers.  UTY  has  the 
experience  to  implement  railway  projects  in  the  region;  it  completed  the  railway  line  from 
Hairatan to Mazar-e-Sharif in Afghanistan in 2010. 
 
19. 
UTY  has  the  capacity  and  experience  to  build  electrified  railways;  it  completed 
electrification of the 114 km Tashkent–Angren section in 2010. Considering the special needs of 
the  project  for  phasing  and  interfacing  works  under  various  components  so  that  it  can  be 
implemented without adverse effect on train operations on the heavily trafficked route, a team of 
international consultants will assist UTY for supervision of construction. 
 
20. 
UTY  is  experienced  in  operations  on  electrified  railways.  It  maintains  and  successfully 
operates a total of 674 km of electrified rail sections, which comprise about 15% of the network 
but carry over 40% of total traffic. To maintain electrified infrastructure, UTY has a well laid-out 
system  comprising  maintenance  companies,  each  responsible  for  about  50  km  of  electrified 
section. The maintenance companies operate from on-duty centers midway in each section, and 
are equipped with rail vehicles with insulated towers for scheduled inspection and maintenance, 
and  breakdown  vehicles  for  transporting  equipment  and  attending  to  medium  and  major 
breakdowns and heavy maintenance work. Similar arrangements are envisaged for the railway 
line electrified under the project. To meet demand for rail traffic, electric locomotives and trained 
operation  and  maintenance  staff  are  available.  Institutional  improvement  will  develop  UTY’s 
management and implementation capacity and contribute to technological improvements. 
  
 

6 

 

 Economic and Financial 

B. 
 
21. 
The  economic  analysis  compared  the  “with-project”  scenario  (electrification  for  electric 
traction) and the “without-project” scenario (status quo with diesel traction) for 25 years (5 years 
of construction and 20 years of operation). The project economic benefits include (i) energy cost 
saving,  (ii)  travel  time  saving  for  freight  traffic,  (iii)  pollution  reduction,  (iv)  diverted  traffic, 
(v) avoidance of diesel locomotives purchase, and (vi) maintenance cost saving. The project is 
economically viable, with an economic internal rate of return at 14.7%. The sensitivity analysis 
was  conducted  to  assess  the  robustness  of  the  results  of  the  economic  analysis.  The  results 
show the project would maintain its economic viability under various unfavorable scenarios.   
 
22. 
The  financial  analysis  compared  the  with-project  scenario  (electrification  for  electric 
traction)  and  the  without-project  scenario  (status  quo  with  diesel  traction)  for  25  years  (2017–
2042) with 10% residual value of capital assets. The project is financially viable, with a financial 
internal rate of return at 13.2% versus the weighted average cost of capital of 2.6%. A sensitivity 
analysis tested the effects of possible unfavorable scenarios with respect to changes in the key 
parameters that affect costs and revenues. For all unfavorable scenarios, the financial internal 
rate of return was found robustly intact. 
 
23. 
UTY  has  a  financial  reporting  system  adequate  to  record  and  compile  transaction 
information  into  the  financial  statement  with  an  appropriate  internal  control  system.  Its  rail 
revenue  steadily  grew  over  2007–2010  at  a  rate  of  20%–40%  per  year  along  with  rail  assets 
that increased rapidly by 30% per year. Profitability remained high, at about 20% of operating 
income ratio. The return on total assets was maintained at 10% and the return on equity at 15%. 
UTY’s profitability, capital adequacy, and liquidity have all been excellent, proving its long-term 
financial sustainability. For 2011–2015, growth is expected to slow down, with a 3%–6% annual 
increase  in  rail  revenue.  Nonetheless,  profitability  will  remain  intact,  with  an  operating  income 
ratio  of  23%  and  net  profit  ratio  of  20%.  UTY’s  financial  performance  will  remain  outstanding 
and its financial position strong. As maintaining profitability will be key to ensuring future capital 
adequacy and liquidity, the loan agreement will include a financial covenant for UTY to maintain 
the operating income ratio at no lower than 20% over 2011–2015. 
 
C. 
 
24. 
Uzbekistan’s performance in governance has progressed steadily, with reforms tackling 
public  financial  management  arrangements,  particularly  budget  execution.15 An  assessment  of 
UTY’s  procurement  capacity  and  financial  management,  among  other  governance-related 
aspects,  found  that  although  UTY  is  a  key  player  in  identifying  reforms  and  the  development 
agenda for railways, it does not adequately provide the government upstream policy advice and 
comprehensive development strategies. Other obstacles included a financial accounting system 
that  has  yet  to  conform  to  international  standards,  and  weak  capacity to  manage  international 
procurement, particularly of consulting services, because the law does not differentiate between 
procurement of goods and consultancy services and because internal rules and procedures are 
lacking.  The  project  will  improve  UTY’s  corporate  governance  on  procurement  and  project 
management through training and consulting services. 
  
25. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and UTY. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the project administration manual (footnote 14). 

Governance 

                                                 
15 The Budget System Law and Treasury Law, approved on 17 December 2007, provides additional cover and better 
practices in managing public finances. The public expenditure reform process for 2007–2018 includes measures to 
increase efficiency, accountability, and transparency. 

7 

 

 Safeguards 

Poverty and Social 

the  baseline  sex-disaggregated  data,  and  conducting 

 
D. 
 
26. 
Railways are important to the people in the project area. They go by train to medical and 
commercial centers in cities and other locations with more developed social infrastructure. The 
project  crosses  two  provinces—Samarkand  and  Kashkadarya—with  a  total  population  of 
5.3 million, most of whom live in cities served by the main stations, such as Marakand, Ayritam, 
Kashkadarya,  and  Karshi.  The  project  beneficiaries  are  existing  and  potential  passengers  and 
freight  customers.  Rural  women  frequently  use  train  services  to  sell  farm  products  and 
handicrafts in cities. The Marakand–Karshi train services are vital for all types of users, and as 
long as trains are cheaper and more convenient (easily accessible, fast, comfortable, with stops 
along  the  way,  and  with  space  for  children  and  goods),  they  will  compete  with  road  transport. 
Cheap,  regular,  safe,  and  fast  access  to  education  and  health  services  in  urban  centers  is 
another benefit, especially for the poor.  
 
27.  Measures  to  promote  gender  equality  and  women’s  empowerment  will  include 
appointing a gender focal point in the executing agency for the implementation of gender-related 
information 
activities,  gathering 
campaigns on HIV/AIDS, among others. The project is not a targeted intervention as it does not 
reduce poverty through standard direct actions at households, or involve specific services that 
tackle  the  geographical  determinants  of  poverty.  The  project  will  improve  railway  operations, 
reduce transport costs, and increase access to basic needs for the people in the project areas. 
The project will not have any negative gender impact. 
 
E. 
 
28. 
The project is classified under environment category B. The due diligence confirmed that 
the  project  does  not  pass  through  any  environmentally  sensitive  areas  and  will  not  result  in 
significantly negative environmental impacts. UTY prepared an initial environmental examination 
(IEE)  according  to  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  national  legislation  and 
regulations.  The  IEE  was  disclosed  on  ADB’s  website  on  1  September  2011.  The  project  will 
have  temporary  and  reversible  environmental  impacts  that  occur  mostly  during  construction. 
Project-affected people were consulted. The IEE includes an environmental management plan 
to  minimize  potential  environmental  impacts  of  the  project.  UTY  will  be  responsible  for 
implementing the plan and submit to ADB an implementation monitoring report annually.  
 
29. 
The  project  will  electrify  the  existing  railway  line  within  the  right-of-way,  and  therefore 
does  not  involve  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  (involuntary  resettlement  category  C).  In 
case  any  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  impacts  occur  during  implementation,  UTY  shall 
prepare  a  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  to  be  submitted  to  ADB  for  approval  prior  to 
awarding  a  civil  works  contract.  The  plan  will  be  implemented  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and  national  legislation  and  regulations.  The  project  is  classified 
under category C for indigenous peoples as it will not affect indigenous peoples as described in 
the Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
F. 
 
30. 
UTY has successfully implemented projects of similar size and nature. Major risks and 
mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in the risk assessment 
and  risk  management  plan. 16  The  integrated  project  benefits  and  impacts  are  expected  to 
outweigh the project costs. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures  

                                                 
16 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2) 

8

Weak 
procurement 
capacity and 
procurement 
delays 

Limited

infrastructure

the region 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Mitigating Measures 
An  international  consultant  under  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  will 
assist UTY in selecting consultants. 

Project  implementation  support,  provided  through  engineering  and  construction 
supervision consultants, will improve UTY staff skills and ensure timely procurement 
and  implementation  and  transparency.  Capacity  improvement  will  be  monitored 
through progress reports. 

The  government  will  ensure  that  the  examination  of  tender  results  and  price 
verifications  by  various  agencies  are  completed  before  submission  of  the  bid 
evaluation report to ADB for contract award.  

The Ministry of Finance synchronizes financial assistance from various development 
partners and manages development coordination centrally. The Uzbekistan Resident 
Mission  will  facilitate  regular  information  exchange  and  policy  dialogue  with 
international and bilateral financial institutions. 

ADB = Asian Development Bank, UTY = Uzbekistan Temir Yullari. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

 
31. 
The  government  and  UTY  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in  the  project  administration  manual  and  loan  documents.  The  government  and  UTY  have 
agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement 
and project agreement. 

32. 
Loan  proceeds  will  not  be  disbursed  for  works  and  goods  until  the  subsidiary  loan 
agreement between the government and UTY (in form and substance satisfactory to ADB) has 
become effective in accordance with its terms. 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
33. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$100,000,000  to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation  Corridor  6  (Marakand–Karshi)  Railway  Electrification  Project  from  ADB’s  ordinary 
capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank 
offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility;  for a  term  of  25  years,  including  a  grace  period  of 
5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board. 
 

 

6 September 2011 

Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
